organization.name: University of Queensland Union
organization.tagline: Your student union representing you at UQ
organization.mission: Representing the diverse interests of students and running services to enhance daily experience
organization.philosophy: Every university student deserves access to support they need to thrive - academically, socially, and mentally

organizational_structure.decision_making: Student feedback and new ideas drive priorities

contact.location: Level 4, Building 21A, University of Queensland, St Lucia

ssaf.name: Student Services and Amenities Fee (SSAF)
ssaf.purpose: Provide and enhance non-academic services on campus for student experience benefit

collectives.name: UQU Disability Collective
collectives.target_group: Students who experience disability, chronic illness, mental illness, neurodiversity and/or are Deaf
collectives.description: Branch of UQU focused on advocacy, support and social connectedness for students with disabilities. Provides safe spaces, peer support, and works with university administration to advocate for student rights.
collectives.mission: Advocacy, support and social connectedness of students at UQ who experience disability, chronic illness, mental illness, neurodiversity and/or are Deaf

membership.eligibility: All students who identify as experiencing disability, chronic illness, mental illness, neurodiversity and/or are Deaf
membership.voting_rights: Equal voting rights for all members

services: Student Access Plan (SAP) guidance and examples
Study skills improvement and barrier alternatives
Advocacy for equitable access to education

facilities.location: Room 21A (opposite Main Course), Student Union Building Level 1

partnerships: UQ Disability, Diversity and Inclusion Advisors (DDIA)

collectives.name: UQU Environment Collective
collectives.target_group: Students, staff and general public interested in environmental issues
collectives.description: Inclusive platform for encouraging sustainable practices on campus, environmental advocacy, and promoting awareness of Queensland's native flora and fauna.
collectives.mission: Encouraging sustainable practices on campus, promoting greater awareness of Queensland's native flora and fauna, and promoting a clean and green St. Lucia

membership.eligibility: All UQ students, staff, and general public

activities: Range of environmental events throughout the year

collectives.name: UQU Goorie Berrimpa
collectives.target_group: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students
collectives.description: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander student collective serving as a 'second home for UQ's deadliest students.' Student-led organization fostering belonging, cultural pride, and connection for First Nations students.
collectives.mission: Fostering a strong sense of belonging, cultural pride, and connection for all First Nations students at UQ, regardless of their background or field of study
collectives.name_meaning: Meeting Place in the language of the Turrbal people

membership.eligibility: All UQ students who identify as Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander

facilities.location: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Unit (ATSISU), Level 2, Bookshop Building (Building 4)

special_features.sports_team: Goorie Goannas - premier sporting team representing Goorie and UQ
special_features.governance: Strong voice on key UQ committees
partnerships: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Unit (ATSISU)

collectives.name: UQU International Collective
collectives.target_group: International students and those interested in cultural diversity
collectives.description: Student collective providing guidance and support for international students throughout their university experience, understanding the challenges of leaving home country behind.
collectives.mission: Guide and support international students throughout their university journey and advocate on behalf of international students to the University of Queensland

membership.eligibility: All international students and any UQ students interested in cultural diversity

services: Guidance and support for international students

collectives.name: UQU Queer Collective
collectives.description: Community group for UQ LGBTQIA+ community facilitating social, charitable, educational, and political events. Proud inheritor of decades of LGBTQIA+ advocacy achievements at UQ.
collectives.mission: Offer regular events, advocacy campaigns, mutual aid, community, friendship, and support for LGBTQIA+ students

membership.eligibility: All UQ community members who identify as queer and/or LGBTQIA+
membership.allies: Welcome at public events as guests

facilities.name: Carden Queer Room
facilities.access: LGBTQIA+ students only (allies welcome as guests)

collectives.name: UQU Student Rights Collective
collectives.description: Peak representative body committed to representing and fighting for UQ students' rights to the University, government, and other stakeholders. Run by elected Student Rights Vice Presidents.
collectives.mission: Representing and advocating on academic and welfare issues, ending student poverty, and improving student welfare

membership.eligibility: All UQ students (represented by elected officials)
membership.governance: Run by elected Student Rights Vice Presidents

initiatives: Placement Bursaries for students in poverty
media_presence: Student debt and education cost advocacy

collectives.name: UQU Women's Collective
collectives.description: Autonomous feminist group representing and advocating for women on campus through events, campaigns, and consciousness-raising. Non-affiliated with political parties or external organizations.
collectives.mission: Represent and advocate for women on campus, engage people with feminist theory, raise consciousness, and have fun

membership.eligibility: All UQ students who identify as women or non-binary

activities: Regular meetings to discuss feminist affairs

organizational_structure.affiliations: Non-affiliated with political parties, external organisations, or values-driven beliefs

compulsory: Bank statements for previous 3 months showing income and expenses

student_exam_support.name: Student Exam Support (SES)
student_exam_support.description: Comprehensive support program during exam periods with food, activities, and wellbeing support

student_id.question: If I forget my student ID card, am I still able to enter the exam room?
student_id.answer: You can get a temporary ID card from Student Central before your exam if you have a photograph on file. Student Central runs extended hours and is open at least 30 minutes before exam start times.

late_arrival.question: What happens if I am late for the exam?
late_arrival.answer: You can enter up to 60 minutes after start time but get no additional time. If your reason meets deferred exam criteria, you may choose to apply for a deferred exam instead.

illness_during_exam.question: What happens if I get sick during an exam and can't finish?
illness_during_exam.answer: Illness during exam is not acceptable for deferred exam, except for sudden medical conditions requiring immediate attention. You need a medical certificate dated the day of exam detailing suddenness, predisposition, seriousness, and impact on ability to complete exam.

missed_exam.question: What do I do if I miss my exam?
missed_exam.answer: Check if you meet exceptional and unavoidable circumstances criteria. If yes, apply for deferred exam. Inform course coordinator ASAP and make SAS appointment to discuss options.

exam_supplies.question: What if I forget a pen, pencil, calculator etc?
exam_supplies.answer: Purchase supplies from UQU ETC (Union Complex, Monday-Friday 9am-3pm) or borrow approved calculators from UQU Reception Level 4 Building 21A during exam periods.

calculator_approval.question: How do I get my calculator approved?
calculator_approval.answer: Go to Student Central to get approved sticker. St Lucia: Building 42 (8am-5pm), Gatton: Level 1 N.W Briton Admin Annexe (8.30am-4.30pm).

clubs.name: 180 Degrees Consulting
clubs.description: Student consulting organization providing pro-bono consulting services. Highly intensive program equivalent to completing a fifth course each semester, offering real-world business experience.

meeting_times.recruitment: End of February (Semester 1) and end of July (Semester 2)

clubs.membership_requirements: Application required through portal - resume, study details, motivation statement
special_features: Pro-bono consulting for real clients
Equivalent workload to fifth university course
Welcome drinks with primary sponsor
Team-based project work
Skills testing and team collaboration focus
Professional networking opportunities

clubs.name: Australia-China Youth Association (ACYA)
clubs.description: Transnational cultural club with chapters across Australia and China, focusing on Chinese and Australian culture exchange. Three main pillars: People-to-People, Education, and Careers.
clubs.membership_requirements: Open to all cultures including Vietnamese, Korean, Caucasian and others
special_features: People-to-People: Day trips (60+ members), dining events, games nights
Education: Language Buddies, Conversation Class, ACE Space, Dumpling Night
Careers: Industry panels with big-name companies, alumni networking, case consulting competition
Volunteering with Tzu Chi (food parcels, recycling)
Host International Ball with BSA, TAISA, UQKISS
Chapters across Australia and China

clubs.name: Queensland University Musical Society (QUMS)
clubs.description: Established in 1912, QUMS is a non-auditioned choir based at UQ, open to both students and the general public. One of the few non-auditioned choirs in Brisbane, performing music from all genres and eras.

meeting_times.post_rehearsal: Coffee every week at local coffee shop or member's house

clubs.membership_requirements: Non-auditioned, all ages and musical abilities welcome, no UQ affiliation required
special_features: Established 1912
Two major concerts per year
Performs at weddings, functions, special events
End of year carolling at shopping centres, Treasury Casino, Queen Street Mall
Social events: QUMSians' Day Out, Rehearsal Camps, Post Concert Parties, Academic Dinner
Rehearsal files provided for home practice
No music reading ability required - they'll teach you

clubs.description: Community focused on using resources to help others as effectively as possible through evidence-based charitable decisions, rational thinking, and global compassion. Connected to the global EA movement.

special_features: Guest speaker-led discussions
Meet-and-greet debates
Charity games

Connected to global EA movement
Supported by GiveWell, 80,000 Hours, EA Australia, Centre for Effective Altruism
UQ chapter for multiple EA organizations
Focus on preventing death and suffering now and in the future
